explanation: Find out about health conditions, including their symptoms and how they're treated.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Aneurysm (abdominal aortic), see Abdominal aortic aneurysm
explanation: An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a swelling in the aorta, the artery that carries blood from the heart to the tummy (abdomen). Most aneurysms do not cause any problems, but they can be serious because there's a risk they could burst (rupture).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Acanthosis nigricans is the name for dry, dark patches of skin that usually appear in the armpits, neck or groin. It could be a sign of an underlying condition, so it needs to be checked by a GP.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Achalasia is a rare disorder of the food pipe (oesophagus), which can make it difficult to swallow food and drink.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Get medical advice as soon as possible if you think you have an acid or chemical burn. You'll need to be treated as soon as possible.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Reflux is when a baby brings up milk, or is sick, during or shortly after feeding. It's very common and usually gets better on its own.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Heartburn is a burning feeling in the chest caused by stomach acid travelling up towards the throat (acid reflux). If it keeps happening, it may be called gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Acne is a common skin condition that affects most people at some point. It causes spots, oily skin and sometimes skin that's hot or painful to touch.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An acoustic neuroma is a type of non-cancerous (benign) brain tumour. It's also known as a vestibular schwannoma.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Acromegaly is a rare condition where the body makes too much of a hormone that can make parts of your body grow bigger. It can be successfully treated.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Solar keratoses, see Actinic keratoses (solar keratoses)
explanation: Actinic keratoses (also called solar keratoses) are dry, scaly patches of skin that have been damaged by the sun. It's not usually serious, but there's a small chance the patches could become skin cancer. Protecting your skin in the sun and watching out for changes can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Actinomycosis is a rare type of bacterial infection. It can be very serious but can usually be treated with antibiotics.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder. It usually happens when a gallstone blocks the cystic duct.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is where your kidneys suddenly stop working properly. It can range from minor loss of kidney function to complete kidney failure.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Leukaemia (acute lymphoblastic), see Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
explanation: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) is a rare type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Leukaemia (acute myeloid), see Acute myeloid leukaemia
explanation: Leukaemia is cancer of the white blood cells. Acute leukaemia means it progresses quickly and aggressively, and usually requires immediate treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Acute pancreatitis is a condition where the pancreas becomes inflamed (swollen) over a short period of time.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a life-threatening illness that can happen when your lungs are not working properly. ARDS is usually a complication of other serious conditions and is treated in hospital.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) is a rare condition where small glands above your kidneys (adrenal glands) do not work properly. It can often be managed with treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Adenomyosis is a condition where the lining of the womb (uterus) starts growing into the muscle in the wall of the womb. There are treatments that can help with any symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) is a condition where the brain works differently to most people. If you have ADHD, you may have trouble with things like concentrating and sitting still. There are things you can do to help manage your symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: ADHD in children and young people
explanation: ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) is a condition where the brain works differently to most people. Children and young people with ADHD may have trouble with things like concentrating and sitting still. There are ways to help manage the symptoms of ADHD.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Read about agoraphobia, a fear of being in situations where escape might be difficult or that help wouldn't be available if things go wrong.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Albinism affects the production of melanin, the pigment that colours skin, hair and eyes. It's a lifelong condition, but it does not get worse over time.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Alcohol misuse is when you drink in a way that's harmful, or when you're dependent on alcohol. To keep health risks from alcohol to a low level, both men and women are advised not to regularly drink more than 14 units a week.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Alcohol poisoning can happen when you drink alcohol quicker than your body can process it. It can make you seriously ill and you may need to go to hospital for treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Liver disease (alcohol-related), see Alcohol-related liver disease
explanation: Alcohol-related liver disease (ARLD) refers to liver damage caused by excess alcohol intake. There are several stages of severity and a range of associated symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Allergic rhinitis is where your nose gets irritated by something you're allergic to, such as pollen, causing sneezing and other symptoms. For most people it's easy to treat with medicines from a pharmacist.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An allergy is where your body reacts to something that's normally harmless like pollen, dust or animal fur. The symptoms can be mild, but for some people they can be very serious.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Altitude sickness can happen when you're at a high altitude. It usually gets better in a few days with rest, but it can sometimes be life-threatening and need treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the UK.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A lazy eye (amblyopia) is when the vision in 1 eye does not develop properly. Rarely, both eyes can be affected.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Amyloidosis is a group of rare conditions where a protein called amyloid builds up in your body. It can affect organs such as your heart, kidneys, liver, nerves or digestive system. It cannot be cured, but there are treatments that may help with symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Iron deficiency anaemia is caused by lack of iron, often because of blood loss or pregnancy. It's treated with iron tablets and by eating iron-rich foods.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia
explanation: Vitamin B12 or B9 (commonly called folate) deficiency anaemia occurs when a lack of vitamin B12 or folate causes the body to produce abnormally large red blood cells that cannot function properly.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Find out about anal cancer, including common symptoms and treatments.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An anal fissure is a small tear in your anus that causes pain when you poo. It usually gets better on its own but if it does not go away, there are treatments that can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An anal fistula is a small tunnel that develops between the end of the bowel and the skin near the opening of the bottom (anus).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening allergic reaction that happens very quickly. It can be caused by food, medicine or insect stings. Call 999 if you think you or someone else is having an anaphylactic reaction.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) affects the development of a person's genitals and reproductive organs.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A brain aneurysm is a swelling in a blood vessel in your brain. If the aneurysm bursts it can cause a bleed on your brain, but this is rare.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Angelman syndrome is a rare genetic condition that affects the nervous system and causes severe physical and learning disabilities.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Angina is a feeling of pain or tightness, usually in your chest. It can be a sign of a heart problem, so it's important to see a GP as soon as possible if you think you may have it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Angioedema is sudden swelling that is often caused by an allergic reaction. It can be very serious if your throat becomes swollen and your breathing is affected. Treatment can help keep the swelling under control.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Human bites, see Animal and human bites
explanation: Most animal and human bites are not serious, but you may need to get medical help if the bite is severe or there are signs of infection.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Swelling in the ankles, feet or legs often goes away on its own. See a GP if it does not get better in a few days.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a long-term condition in which the spine and other areas of the body become inflamed.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Anorexia nervosa (often called anorexia) is an eating disorder where you feel a need to keep your weight as low as possible.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Aphasia (also called dysphasia) is a condition that makes it difficult to communicate. It can make it hard to speak, read, write and understand others. It's often caused by a stroke or brain injury. There's no cure, but people usually improve with treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Appendicitis is swelling and infection in your appendix (part of your bowel). It usually causes pain in the lower right side of your abdomen (tummy). It needs urgent treatment in hospital.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Heart rhythm problems (arrhythmia) are when your heart beats too quickly or too slowly, or your heartbeat is not steady. It might not be serious but see a GP if you think you're having symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Arthritis is a condition that causes pain, swelling and stiffness in one or more joints. It can make moving the affected joints difficult.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Asbestosis is a rare but serious lung condition that affects people exposed to asbestos (a building material used from the 1950s to the 1990s). It cannot be cured, but treatment may improve the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Aspergillosis is a condition caused by aspergillus mould. There are several different types of aspergillosis. Most affect the lungs and cause breathing difficulties.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Asthma is a common condition that affects your breathing. It cannot currently be cured, but if it's well treated you should not have problems with symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Astigmatism is a common eye condition that can cause blurry vision. It's usually treated using glasses or contact lenses.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ataxia is a term for a group of disorders that affect co-ordination, balance and speech.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Atherosclerosis is where your arteries become narrowed, making it difficult for blood to flow through them. It increases your risk of heart attack and stroke.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Athlete's foot is a common fungal infection that affects the feet. You can usually treat it with creams, sprays or powders from a pharmacy, but it can keep coming back.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Atopic eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a common skin condition that causes itchy skin. It affects people of all ages but is most common in young children. It cannot be cured, but treatment can help manage the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Polycystic kidney disease (autosomal dominant), see Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
explanation: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is an inherited condition that causes small fluid-filled sacs called cysts to develop in the kidneys.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Polycystic kidney disease (autosomal recessive), see Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
explanation: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is a rare inherited childhood condition where the development of the kidneys and liver is abnormal. Over time, these organs may fail.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Back pain, particularly lower back pain, is very common. It usually improves within a few weeks but can sometimes last longer or keep coming back. There are things you can do to help ease the pain.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A Baker's cyst (popliteal cyst) is a fluid-filled lump at the back of the knee. It may get better on its own or by treating the condition causing it, but you should get any lumps checked by a GP.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Balanitis is when the head of the penis is swollen and sore. It's not usually serious but it's important to see a GP to find out what's causing it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A Bartholin’s cyst is a lump near the opening of the vagina. They do not always need treatment, but always get any lumps checked by a GP.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bedbugs are small insects that often live on furniture or bedding. Their bites can be itchy, but do not usually cause other health problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Behçet's disease, or Behçet's syndrome, is a rare and poorly understood condition that results in inflammation of the blood vessels and tissues.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bell's palsy is temporary weakness or lack of movement that usually affects 1 side of the face. Treatment with steroids can help and most people get better within 6 months.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An enlarged prostate (sometimes called benign prostate enlargement) is when your prostate gets bigger. It's common and is not usually serious, but there are treatments that can help if you need them.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Find out about bile duct cancer, including what the symptoms are, what causes it, how it's diagnosed and treated, and where to get further support.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Schistosomiasis, also called bilharzia, is an infection caused by tiny worms that live in ponds, lakes and rivers. It's not found in the UK, but there's a risk of catching it in some parts of the world.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Read about binge eating disorder, which is when a person feels compelled to overeat on a regular basis. Find out about the symptoms, treatments and possible causes.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition where you have extreme mood changes. Medicines and talking therapy can help manage it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bladder cancer is cancer that's found anywhere in your bladder. It's more common if you're over the age of 60.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Interstitial cystitis, see Bladder pain syndrome (BPS)
explanation: Bladder pain syndrome (BPS), also known as interstitial cystitis, is a condition that causes pain in your lower tummy or back and makes you feel like you want to pee all the time. There's currently no cure, but treatments can help manage your symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bladder stones are hard lumps of minerals that can form inside the bladder when it's not completely empty of urine.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Blepharitis causes swollen, itchy eyelids. It's not usually serious and can often be treated by washing your eyelids every day.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Read about borderline personality disorder. Personality disorders can cause a range of distressing symptoms and patterns of abnormal behaviour.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Botulism is a rare but life-threatening condition caused by toxins produced by Clostridium botulinum bacteria.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bowel cancer is cancer found anywhere in the large bowel, which includes the colon and rectum. It's one of the most common types of cancer in the UK.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bowel incontinence is when you cannot control when you poo. See a GP if you think you have bowel incontinence as there are treatments that can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bowel polyps are small growths on the lining of the large intestine (colon) or rectum. They're very common and not usually serious, but sometimes they can lead to bowel cancer.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bowen's disease is a very early form of skin cancer that's easily treatable. The main sign is a red, scaly patch on the skin.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Flat head syndrome, see Flat head syndrome (plagiocephaly and brachycephaly)
explanation: Some babies get a flat head when they’re a few months old because they spend a lot of time lying down. It’s usually nothing to worry about and gets better as they get older.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A brain abscess is a pus-filled swelling in the brain. It usually occurs when bacteria or fungi enter the brain tissue after an infection or severe head injury.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Brain death (also known as brain stem death) is when a person on an artificial life support machine no longer has any brain functions. This means they will not regain consciousness or be able to breathe without support.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is a rare type of stroke that causes bleeding on the brain. It's a life-threatening emergency that needs treatment in hospital as soon as possible.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A brain tumour is a growth of cells in the brain that multiplies in an abnormal, uncontrollable way.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Breast cancer is cancer that's found in the breasts or breast tissue in the chest. Anyone can get it, including men.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Breast cancer is cancer that's found in the breasts. It's the most common type of cancer in women in the UK. Anyone can get breast cancer.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Breath-holding is when a baby or child stops breathing for up to 1 minute and may faint. It can happen when a child is frightened, upset, angry, or has a sudden shock or pain. It's usually harmless but can be scary for parents, particularly when it happens for the first time.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Get medical advice as soon as possible if you think you've broken your ankle. It may need treatment to heal properly.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Get medical advice as soon as possible if you think you have broken your arm or wrist. Any possible breaks need to be treated as soon as possible.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A broken collarbone is usually caused by an injury to your shoulder. Get medical advice as soon as possible if you think you have a broken collarbone.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Get medical advice as soon as possible if you think you have broken a finger or thumb. It may need treatment to heal properly. A broken bone is also known as a fracture.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Get medical advice as soon as possible if you think you've broken your leg.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A broken nose usually heals on its own within 3 weeks. Get medical help if it's not getting better or your nose has changed shape.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bruised or broken ribs can be very painful, but usually heal by themselves.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A broken toe can be painful, but you do not usually need to go to hospital. There are things you can do to treat it at home.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bronchiectasis is a condition where the airways in your lungs are damaged and produce a lot of phlegm (mucus). It cannot usually be cured, but treatment can help manage it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bronchiolitis is a common chest infection that affects babies and children under 2. It's usually mild and can be treated at home, but it can be serious.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bronchitis is inflammation of the airways in the lungs that is usually caused by an infection. It often gets better without treatment in around 3 weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Brucellosis is an infection you can catch from unpasteurised milk and cheese or from contact with infected animals. It's very rare in the UK.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Brugada syndrome is a rare heart condition that's usually inherited. It can affect your heart rhythm and can be life-threatening, but there are things you can do to reduce the risk of serious problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bulimia (bulimia nervosa) is an eating disorder and serious mental health condition. It can affect anyone and treatment may take time, but you can recover from it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bullous pemphigoid is a rare skin condition that mainly affects people over the age of 60. It may last a few years and can be serious, but treatment helps.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bunions are bony lumps that form on the side of the feet. Surgery is the only way to get rid of them, but there are things you can do to ease any pain they cause.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Burns and scalds are damage to the skin usually caused by heat. Both are treated in the same way.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Bursitis is when the fluid-filled sacs (bursa) that cushion the joints have become painful and swollen (inflamed). It can usually be treated at home and should go away in a few weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cancer is a condition where cells in the body grow in an uncontrolled way. Speak to a GP if you notice any symptoms that are not normal for you.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Carbon monoxide is a poisonous gas that can make you seriously ill if you breathe it in. Carbon monoxide can be made by fires and appliances that burn gas, wood, oil or coal.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cardiomyopathy is a general term for diseases of the heart muscle, where the walls of the heart chambers have become stretched, thickened or stiff. This affects the heart's ability to pump blood around the body.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the name for a group of conditions that affect your heart and blood vessels. It can often be prevented by having a healthy lifestyle or taking medicines if you need them.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is pressure on a nerve in your wrist. It causes tingling, numbness and pain in your hand and fingers. You can often treat it yourself, but it can take months to get better.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cataracts occur when changes in the lens of the eye cause it to become less transparent (clear). This results in cloudy or misty vision.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cataracts is where the lens in your eye becomes cloudy, causing blurred vision and loss of sight. It usually affects older adults and can be treated with surgery.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Catarrh is a build-up of mucus in your nose and sinuses and phlegm in your throat. It usually clears up by itself but see a GP if it lasts longer than a few weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A cavernoma is a cluster of abnormal blood vessels, usually found in the brain and spinal cord.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cellulitis is a skin infection that's treated with antibiotics. It can be serious if it's not treated quickly.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cerebral palsy is the name for a group of lifelong conditions that affect movement and co-ordination. It's caused by a problem with the brain that develops before, during or soon after birth.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cervical cancer is cancer that's found anywhere in the cervix, which is the opening between the vagina and the womb.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cervical spondylosis is a common condition that can cause neck and shoulder pain, often in people over 40. A GP should check more serious cases affecting the spine.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) is a group of inherited conditions that damage the peripheral nerves.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Charles Bonnet syndrome is a condition where you see things that are not real (hallucinations). It can happen if you've lost a lot of your sight. It's not caused by a mental health problem or dementia.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A chest infection is an infection of the lungs or large airways. Some chest infections are mild and clear up on their own, but others can be severe and life threatening.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A Chiari malformation, previously called an Arnold-Chiari malformation, is where the lower part of the brain pushes down into the spinal canal.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Tooth (chipped or broken), see Chipped, broken or cracked tooth
explanation: Chipping, breaking or cracking a tooth is usually not serious. A dentist should be able to treat it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Chlamydia is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) passed on through unprotected sex (sex without a condom). It’s treated with antibiotics. If not treated it can cause serious health problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cholera is an infection that can cause severe diarrhoea. It's not found in the UK, but there's a very small risk of getting it while travelling in some parts of the world.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A cholesteatoma is a build-up of dead cells inside your ear that can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness. It's rare and can be treated with surgery.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: HEART UK has information about inherited high cholesterol that starts at a young age (familial hypercholesterolaemia).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Myalgic encephalomyelitis or chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS)
explanation: Myalgic encephalomyelitis, also called chronic fatigue syndrome or ME/CFS, is a long-term condition that can affect different parts of the body. The most common symptom is extreme tiredness. The cause of ME/CFS is unknown.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Kidney failure, see Chronic kidney disease
explanation: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a long-term condition where the kidneys do not work as well as they should.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Leukaemia (chronic lymphocytic), see Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
explanation: It's important to get any symptoms of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia checked as soon as possible. Finding it early can mean it's more treatable.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) is a rare type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and white blood cells.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the name for a group of lung conditions that cause breathing difficulties.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Chronic pancreatitis is a long-term condition where the pancreas is inflamed, scarred and painful. There's no cure, but there are treatments for the problems it can cause.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) is a brain condition thought to be linked to repeated head injuries and blows to the head. It slowly gets worse over time and leads to dementia, but the right help and support can manage the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cirrhosis is a condition where the liver is severely damaged. It can be life-threatening, but treatments and lifestyle changes can help stop it getting worse.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare and fatal condition that affects the brain. It causes brain damage that worsens rapidly over time.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Claustrophobia is the irrational fear of confined spaces.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A cleft is a gap or split in the upper lip and/or roof of the mouth (palate). It is present from birth.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cluster headaches are severe attacks of pain that can last for long periods. They're not caused by another illness. They can have a real impact on your life, but there are treatments that can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Tailbone pain is pain in the bone at the base of the spine (coccyx), near the top of your bottom. There are things you can do to ease the pain, but get medical help if it does not get better after a few weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Coeliac disease is a condition where your immune system attacks your own tissues when you eat gluten. This damages your gut (small intestine) so your body cannot properly take in nutrients.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cold sores are common and usually clear up on their own within 10 days. There are things you can do to help ease the pain.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Colic is when a baby cries a lot but there's no obvious cause. It's a common problem that should get better by around 3 or 4 months of age. But call NHS 111 or see a GP if you're worried.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Colour vision deficiency (colour blindness) is where you see colours differently to most people, and have difficulty telling colours apart. There's no treatment for colour vision deficiency that runs in families, but people usually adapt to living with it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: You can often treat a cold without seeing a GP. You should begin to feel better in about 1 to 2 weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Compartment syndrome is an increase in pressure inside a muscle, which restricts blood flow and causes pain. If it happens suddenly, it can be serious and need treatment as soon as possible.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is a poorly understood condition where a person experiences persistent severe and debilitating pain.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Most head injuries are not serious, but it's important to get medical help if you or your child have any symptoms after a head injury. You might have concussion (temporary brain injury) that can last a few weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Congenital heart disease is when you are born with a heart defect, like a hole in your heart. This can affect the way blood flows around your body. Treatments include medicine and sometimes surgery.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Hip dysplasia, see Developmental dysplasia of the hip
explanation: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is a condition where the "ball and socket" joint of the hip does not properly form in babies and young children.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Conjunctivitis is an eye condition caused by infection or allergies. It usually gets better in a couple of weeks without treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Constipation is where you have changes to how you poo, including not pooing as often or finding it hard to poo. It's common and it affects people of all ages. You can usually treat it with simple changes to your diet and lifestyle.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Contact dermatitis is a type of eczema triggered by contact with a particular substance.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Corns and calluses are hard or thick areas of skin that can be painful. They're not often serious. There are things you can try to ease them yourself.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Heart disease (coronary), see Coronary heart disease
explanation: Coronary heart disease (CHD) is a major cause of death in the UK and worldwide. CHD is sometimes called ischaemic heart disease or coronary artery disease.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Get NHS advice about COVID-19, including its symptoms and what to do, how to avoid catching and spreading it, treatments, vaccinations and long-term effects.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Corticobasal degeneration (CBD) is a rare condition that can cause gradually worsening problems with movement, speech, memory and swallowing.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Costochondritis is inflammation where your ribs join the bone in the middle of your chest (breastbone). It can cause sharp chest pain, especially when moving or breathing. It usually gets better on its own over time.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cradle cap is a harmless skin condition that's common in babies. It usually goes away on its own within a few months, but there are things you can try to make it better.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Craniosynostosis is a rare condition where a baby's skull does not grow properly and their head becomes an unusual shape. It's usually treated with surgery.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Crohn's disease is a long-term condition where part of your gut becomes inflamed. It cannot currently be cured, but there are treatments that can help prevent or manage the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Croup is a common condition that mainly affects babies' and young children's airways. It's usually mild, but it's important to call NHS 111 or see a GP if you think your child has croup. This is because they may need treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cushing's syndrome is a rare condition caused by having too much of a hormone called cortisol in your body. You're more likely to get it if you take high doses of steroid medicines for a long time.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Most cuts and grazes can be treated at home and will start to heal in a few days. But some wounds may need to be treated by a medical professional if there's a risk of infection or the cut is serious.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cyclical vomiting syndrome is a rare condition that causes severe episodes of feeling sick (nausea) and being sick (vomiting). Avoiding things that trigger it and taking medicines can help manage the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cystitis is a urinary tract infection (UTI) that affects the bladder. It's common, particularly in women. It often gets better by itself, but may sometimes be treated with antibiotics.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common virus that's usually harmless. Sometimes it causes problems in babies and people with a weakened immune system.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dandruff is a common skin condition. It's not harmful and you cannot catch it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Deafblindness is a combination of sight and hearing loss that affects a person's ability to communicate, access information and get around.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hearing loss is common, particularly as you get older. See a GP if you have problems with your hearing. It could be caused by something that can be easily treated.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dehydration means your body loses more fluids than you take in. If it's not treated, it can get worse and become a serious problem.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: This guide has information for people with dementia and their families and friends.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Frontotemporal dementia is an uncommon type of dementia that causes problems with behaviour and language.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Vascular dementia is a common type of dementia caused by reduced blood flow to the brain. It's estimated to affect around 180,000 people in the UK.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), also known as Lewy body dementia, is one of the most common types of dementia.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dengue, also known as dengue fever, is an infection spread by mosquitoes. It's not usually serious and often gets better on its own. Some people get a more severe type of dengue, but this is rare.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A dental abscess is a build-up of pus in the teeth or gums caused by an infection. It needs urgent treatment by a dentist. A dental abscess will not go away on its own.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Depression is a low mood that can last a long time or keep returning, affecting your everyday life.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Depression is a low mood that lasts for weeks or months and affects your daily life.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Retinal detachment, see Detached retina (retinal detachment)
explanation: A detached retina is when the thin layer at the back of your eye (retina) becomes loose. It needs to be treated quickly to stop it permanently affecting your sight.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Dyspraxia in children, see Developmental co-ordination disorder (dyspraxia) in children
explanation: Developmental co-ordination disorder (DCD), also known as dyspraxia, is a condition affecting physical co-ordination. It causes a child to perform less well than expected in daily activities for their age, and appear to move clumsily.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Diabetes is a condition that causes your blood glucose (sugar) level to become too high.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Type 1 diabetes is a condition where your body cannot make a hormone called insulin. This causes the level of glucose (sugar) in your blood to get too high.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Type 2 diabetes is when a hormone called insulin does not work properly or there is not enough of it. This causes the level of glucose (sugar) in your blood to become too high. It affects adults and sometimes children.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gestational diabetes is high blood sugar (glucose) that develops during pregnancy and usually disappears after giving birth.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Diabetes insipidus is a rare condition where you pee a lot and often feel thirsty.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious condition that can happen in people with diabetes. It's where a lack of insulin causes harmful substances called ketones to build up in the blood. It can be life threatening and needs urgent treatment in hospital.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Diabetic retinopathy is an eye condition caused by diabetes. It can lead to sight loss, but finding and treating it early reduces the risk.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Intersex, see Differences in sex development
explanation: Differences in sex development (DSD) is a group of rare conditions involving genes, hormones and reproductive organs, including genitals. It means a person's sex development is different to most other people's.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: DiGeorge syndrome is a condition present from birth that can cause a range of lifelong problems, including heart defects and learning difficulties.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Diphtheria is a contagious infection that affects the nose and throat, and sometimes the skin. It's rare in the UK, but there's a small risk of catching it if you travel to some parts of the world.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Discoid eczema, also known as nummular or discoid dermatitis, is a long-term (chronic) skin condition that causes skin to become itchy, swollen and cracked in circular or oval patches.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A dislocated kneecap is where your kneecap (patella) moves out of place. It is usually caused by an injury to the knee. Get medical advice as soon as possible if you think you have a dislocated kneecap.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A dislocated shoulder is when your upper arm bone comes out of place from your shoulder socket.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dissociative disorders are a range of conditions that can cause physical and psychological problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Diverticular disease and diverticulitis are conditions that affect the large intestine (bowel), causing tummy (abdominal) pain and other symptoms. They're caused by small bulges or pouches in the walls of the intestine called diverticula.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Down's syndrome is when you're born with an extra chromosome.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dupuytren's contracture is when 1 or more fingers bend in towards your palm. There's no cure, but your fingers can be straightened with surgery if it's severe.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: DVT (deep vein thrombosis) is a blood clot in a vein, usually in the leg. DVT can be dangerous. Get medical help as soon as possible if you think you have DVT.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Restricted growth, also called dwarfism or short stature, is when you are shorter than most people. It has many different causes. Treatment depends on what's causing it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dysarthria is where you have difficulty speaking because the muscles you use for speech are weak. It can be caused by conditions that damage your brain or nerves and some medicines. Speech and language therapy can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dyspraxia, also known as developmental co-ordination disorder (DCD), is a common disorder that affects movement and co-ordination.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Dystonia is the name for uncontrolled and sometimes painful muscle movements (spasms). It's usually a lifelong problem, but treatment can help relieve the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ear infections are very common, particularly in children. They often get better on their own within 3 days.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A perforated (burst) eardrum is a hole or tear in your eardrum. It usually gets better on its own within 2 months, but you may need treatment such as antibiotics.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Puberty (early or delayed), see Early or delayed puberty
explanation: Puberty is when a child's body begins to develop and change as they become an adult.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Menopause (early), see Early or premature menopause
explanation: Early menopause is when you stop having regular periods before the age of 45. Premature menopause is if this happens before the age of 40. It can happen naturally or be caused by treatment for other conditions.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Earwax normally just falls out on its own. When it's blocking your ears, a pharmacist can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ebola virus disease is a serious, rare infection usually found in certain parts of Africa. It's caught by coming into contact with the body fluids of an infected person or wild animal.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An ectopic pregnancy is when a fertilised egg implants itself outside of the womb, usually in one of the fallopian tubes.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ectropion is when your lower eyelid droops or sags away from your eye and turns outwards. It's not usually serious but can be uncomfortable.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Varicose eczema, also known as venous, gravitational or stasis eczema, is a long-term skin condition that affects the lower legs. It's common in people with varicose veins.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Edwards’ syndrome, also called trisomy 18, is a rare genetic condition that cannot currently be cured. It’s often diagnosed in pregnancy or soon after a baby is born.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ehlers-Danlos syndromes (EDS) are a group of rare inherited conditions that affect connective tissue.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ejaculation problems are common sexual problems in men.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Encephalitis is an uncommon but serious condition in which the brain becomes inflamed (swollen).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Endocarditis is a rare and potentially fatal infection of the inner lining of the heart (the endocardium). It's most commonly caused by bacteria entering the blood and travelling to the heart.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: It's important to get any symptoms of womb cancer checked as soon as possible. Finding it earlier makes it easier to treat.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Endometriosis is where cells similar to those in the lining of the womb (uterus) grow in other parts of the body. It can have a big impact on your life, but there are treatments that can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) is the name for a group of rare inherited skin disorders that cause the skin to become very fragile. Any trauma or friction to the skin can cause painful blisters.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Epididymitis is where a tube (the epididymis) behind the testicles becomes swollen and painful. It's often caused by an infection and is usually treated with antibiotics.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Epiglottitis is swelling of your epiglottis, the flap that covers your windpipe when you swallow. Epiglottitis can block your windpipe, even when you're not swallowing, making it difficult to breathe. It's a medical emergency and needs to be treated in hospital straight away.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Epilepsy is a condition that affects your brain and causes seizures (sometimes called fits). It cannot currently be cured, but treatment can often help manage it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Erectile dysfunction (impotence) is very common, particularly in men over 40. It's usually nothing to worry about, but see a GP if it keeps happening.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Erythema multiforme is a skin condition that can be caused by an infection or some medicines. It usually gets better on its own in 2 to 4 weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Erythema nodosum is a condition that causes painful patches of skin that look red or darker than the surrounding skin. It usually goes away by itself, but it can sometimes be a sign of something serious like an inflammatory bowel condition, such as Crohn's disease.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Erythrocytosis, sometimes called polycythaemia, means having a high concentration of red blood cells in your blood.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Erythromelalgia is a rare condition that causes burning pain, redness and hot skin, mainly in the feet. It can be constant or come and go, but treatment and avoiding triggers can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia) is a condition where people fall asleep repeatedly during the day.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.
