explanation: Excessive sweating is common and can affect the whole body or just certain areas. Sometimes it gets better with age but there are things you can do and treatments that can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A herpes simplex eye infection is a viral infection that can cause a painful, red eye. It's also called eye herpes or ocular herpes. It's important to get treatment because it can sometimes affect your sight.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Minor eye injuries, such as shampoo or dust in your eye, often get better on their own within a day. Get medical help if you have a chemical in your eye or something pierces it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Find out about fabricated or induced illness (FII), which is a rare form of child abuse where a parent or carer exaggerates or deliberately causes symptoms of illness in the child.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Prosopagnosia, also called face blindness, is a condition where you have difficulty recognising people's faces. There is no treatment, but there are things you can do to help you recognise people.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Anyone can have a fall, but it's more likely if you're older or have mobility problems. Making changes to prevent falls can help you avoid injuries and keep your confidence and independence.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: If you drink alcohol during pregnancy you risk causing harm to your baby. Sometimes this can result in mental and physical problems in the baby, called fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Fibroids are non-cancerous growths that develop in or around the womb (uterus).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Fibromyalgia, also called fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS), is a long-term condition that causes pain all over the body.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Flat feet, or "fallen arches", are where your feet press flat on the ground. They're common and usually nothing to worry about.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Flu will often get better on its own, but it can make some people seriously ill. It's important to get the flu vaccine if you're advised to.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A food allergy is where your body reacts to certain foods. It's often mild, but can be very serious for some people.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A food intolerance is when you have difficulty digesting certain foods or ingredients in food. It's not usually serious, but eating the food you're intolerant to can make you feel unwell.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Food poisoning is rarely serious and usually gets better within a week. You can normally treat yourself or your child at home.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Foot drop (drop foot) is where it's difficult to lift or move your foot and toes. It usually affects 1 foot and can affect the way you walk.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: It's normal for babies and young boys to have a tight foreskin (phimosis), but adults can also be affected. See a GP if your or your child's foreskin is sore or swollen.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Frostbite happens when your skin freezes after being in very cold temperatures. The skin needs to be warmed as soon as possible. Get medical help if you think you or someone else has frostbite.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Frozen shoulder means your shoulder is painful and stiff for months, sometimes years. It can be treated with shoulder exercises and painkillers.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Many people have persistent physical symptoms, such as dizziness or pain, that don't appear to be caused by a medical condition.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Nail fungal infection, see Fungal nail infection
explanation: You may have a fungal nail infection if your nail is brittle, discoloured or thicker than usual. These types of infections are not serious but they can take a long time to treat.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Find out about gallbladder cancer, including the symptoms, causes, tests, treatments, and where to get support.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gallstones are small stones that form in the gallbladder. Most people who have them do not get symptoms. If gallstones are causing pain in your tummy, you may need surgery to remove your gallbladder.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A ganglion cyst is a fluid filled lump under the skin that usually appears on the wrist or hand. Ganglion cysts are common and often get better on their own. There are treatments if it's painful or affects joint movement.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gangrene is a serious condition where a loss of blood supply causes body tissue to die. It can affect any part of the body but typically starts in the toes, feet, fingers and hands.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gastritis is when the lining of your stomach becomes irritated (inflamed). It can cause pain, indigestion and feeling sick. Treatments include antacids, alginates and antibiotics.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gastroparesis is where food passes through the stomach slower than it should. It's a long-term condition that can be managed with diet changes, medicines and other treatments.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gender dysphoria is a term that describes a sense of unease that a person may have because of a mismatch between their biological sex and their gender identity.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD) is a common mental health condition where you often feel very anxious about lots of different things.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) passed on through vaginal, anal and oral sex. Treatment from a sexual health clinic can help. Symptoms clear up on their own but can come back.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Genital warts are small, rough lumps that can appear around the vagina, penis or anus. They're a common sexually transmitted infection (STI). Treatment from a sexual health clinic can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Rubella (german measles) is a rare illness that causes a spotty rash. It usually gets better in about a week, but it can be serious if you get it when you're pregnant.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) is where the arteries, particularly those at the side of the head (the temples), become inflamed. It's serious and needs urgent treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Giardiasis is a tummy bug that causes symptoms like diarrhoea, farting and bloating. It usually goes away in about a week if it's treated, but it can sometimes last much longer.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gilbert's syndrome is a common genetic condition that may cause mild jaundice (yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes) that comes and goes. It does not usually need any treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Glandular fever is a viral infection that mostly affects teenagers and young adults. It gets better without treatment, but it can last for weeks and make you feel very ill.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Glaucoma is an eye condition where the main nerve, which connects the eye to the brain, becomes damaged. It's most common in adults aged 50 and over and can cause vision loss if it's not diagnosed and treated early.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Glomerulonephritis is damage to the tiny filters inside your kidneys (the glomeruli). It's often caused by your immune system attacking healthy body tissue.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Glue ear is where the middle part of the ear canal fills up with fluid. This can cause temporary hearing loss. It usually clears up within 3 months, but see a GP about any hearing problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A goitre is a lump or swelling at the front of the neck caused by a swollen thyroid. The thyroid is a small gland in your neck that makes hormones. Goitres are not usually serious but should be checked by a GP.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) passed on through unprotected sex (sex without a condom). It's treated with antibiotics. If it's not treated, it can cause serious health problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gout is a type of arthritis that causes sudden, severe joint pain. Painkillers can help the pain and healthier lifestyle choices can prevent future attacks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Granuloma annulare is a skin condition that often looks like a ring of bumps. It sometimes clears up without treatment, but it can take a long time and it may come back. See a GP if you have bumps or lumps on your skin that do not go away in a few weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a rare condition where blood vessels become inflamed, mainly in the ears, nose, sinuses, kidneys and lungs. It can be serious if not treated but medicines can help manage the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Group B strep is a type of bacteria called streptococcal bacteria. It's very common in both men and women and usually lives in the bottom (rectum) or vagina.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Growing pains is a term used for leg pain that is common in children aged 3 to 12. It's harmless and usually gets better on its own. The pain can be treated with painkillers like paracetamol.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Guillain-Barré (pronounced ghee-yan bar-ray) syndrome is a rare condition that affects the nerves. It's serious and needs urgent treatment in hospital.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gum disease is where the gums become red, swollen and sore, and bleed. It's very common, but it's important to get it checked by a dentist.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Gynaecomastia is where men have bigger breasts than usual. It's common and may not need treatment, but can sometimes be caused by other conditions.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Haemochromatosis is an inherited condition where iron levels in the body slowly build up over many years.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Haemophilia is a rare condition that affects the way your blood clots, meaning you bleed more easily than other people. It cannot usually be cured, but treatment can help control your symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Hib, see Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
explanation: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) is a type of bacteria that can cause life-threatening infections. Babies and children are most at risk of getting seriously ill and can get vaccinated against it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Piles (haemorrhoids) are lumps inside and around your bottom (anus). They often get better on their own after a few days. There are things you can do to treat and prevent piles.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hamstrings are the muscles at the back of your thighs. You can injure them when playing sports or exercising. You can usually treat mild injuries yourself.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hand, foot and mouth disease is a common childhood illness that can also affect adults. It usually gets better on its own in 7 to 10 days.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hay fever is a common allergy that causes sneezing, coughing and itchy eyes. You cannot cure it, but there are things you can do to help your symptoms, or medicines you can take to help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Head lice and nits are very common in young children and their families. They are not caused by dirty hair and are picked up by head-to-head contact.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Tension headaches are very common and many people get them. You can treat them yourself with painkillers but see a GP if you have several headaches a week or they're severe.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Health anxiety is when you spend so much time worrying you're ill, or going to get ill, that it starts to take over your life. It's related to obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A heart attack (myocardial infarction or MI) is a serious medical emergency in which the supply of blood to the heart is suddenly blocked, usually by a blood clot.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Heart block is a condition where your heart beats too slowly or your heartbeat is not steady. It can happen if the electrical impulses in your heart are blocked or delayed. You usually only need treatment if it's causing symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Heart failure means that the heart is unable to pump blood around the body properly. It usually happens because the heart has become too weak or stiff.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Heart valve disease is where 1 or more of the valves in your heart does not work as it should. It does not always need treatment, but some people will need medicines or surgery.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Heat exhaustion does not usually need emergency medical help if you can cool down within 30 minutes. If it turns into heatstroke, it needs to be treated as an emergency.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Sweat rash, see Heat rash (prickly heat)
explanation: Heat rash is uncomfortable, but usually harmless. It usually gets better on its own after a few days.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Many women have heavy periods (also called menorrhagia) and they may be normal for you. They can affect anyone who has periods. Treatment can help if they're affecting your daily life.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) affects the blood vessels and causes a spotty rash. It's not usually serious, but can sometimes lead to kidney problems. It's more common in children, but adults can get it too.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hepatitis is when your liver becomes inflamed, usually due to a virus or drinking too much alcohol over a long period of time. Some types of hepatitis can lead to serious problems if not treated.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hepatitis A is a liver infection that is spread in the poo of an infected person. Most people who get it get better within a few months.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hepatitis B is a liver infection spread through blood and body fluids. You can be vaccinated against hepatitis B and the chance of getting it in the UK is low. The infection usually only lasts for a few months, but some people can have it long term.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hepatitis C is a virus that can infect the liver. If left untreated, it can sometimes cause serious and potentially life-threatening damage to the liver over many years.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hereditary haemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is an inherited genetic disorder that affects the blood vessels. It's also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hereditary spastic paraplegia is a general term for a group of rare inherited disorders that cause weakness and stiffness in the leg muscles. Symptoms gradually get worse over time.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A hernia occurs when an internal part of the body pushes through a weakness in the muscle or surrounding tissue wall.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A hiatus hernia is when part of your stomach moves up into your chest. It's very common if you're over 50. It does not normally need treatment if it's not causing you problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An umbilical hernia is a bulge in the tummy caused by part of the bowel, or surrounding fat, pushing through a weakness in the muscles.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Neonatal herpes is a herpes infection in a young baby. The younger the baby, the more vulnerable they are to the harmful effects of infection.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Whitlow finger, see Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger)
explanation: Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger) is a painful infection of the finger caused by the herpes virus. It's easily treated but can come back.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a painful, long-term skin condition that causes skin abscesses and scarring on the skin.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: High blood sugar (hyperglycaemia) is where the level of sugar in your blood is too high. It mainly affects people with diabetes and can be serious if not treated.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hirschsprung's disease is a rare condition that causes poo to become stuck in the bowels. It's mainly diagnosed in babies and young children.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hodgkin lymphoma is an uncommon cancer that affects the white blood cells that help you fight infection (lymphocytes).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the name of a very common group of viruses. They do not cause any problems in most people, but some types can cause genital warts or cancer.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Huntington's disease is an inherited condition that affects your movement, thinking and mood. It gets worse over time and cannot currently be cured, but there are treatments to help with the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hydrocephalus is a build-up of fluid in the brain. The excess fluid puts pressure on the brain, which can damage it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hydronephrosis is where one or both of your kidneys become swollen up from a build-up of pee. It needs treatment as soon as possible to avoid any long-term problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hyperacusis is when everyday sounds seem much louder to you than they should. Treatment can help. See a GP if you think you have hyperacusis.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hyperparathyroidism is a condition where your body produces too much calcium, which can cause problems with your blood, bones and kidneys. It can be treated with surgery and medicines.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An overactive thyroid, also known as hyperthyroidism or thyrotoxicosis, is where the thyroid gland produces too much of the thyroid hormones.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia or a hypo) is usually where your blood sugar (glucose) is below 4mmol/L. It needs to be treated quickly to stop it getting worse, but you can usually treat it yourself.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hypoparathyroidism (sometime called "hypopara") is a rare condition where small glands in your neck (parathyroid glands) do not work properly. It can lead to problems with your bones, muscles and nerves, but can usually be treated by taking supplements.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Hypothermia is a dangerous drop in body temperature below 35C (normal body temperature is around 37C). It's a medical emergency that needs to be treated in hospital.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism) is a common condition where the thyroid gland in your neck does not make enough hormones. This can cause symptoms like tiredness and weight gain. It can be managed with treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a term used to describe conditions that cause severe tummy pain and diarrhoea. IBD is long-term, but there are treatments that can help with the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ichthyosis is a group of rare skin conditions that cause dry, scaly skin. It's usually something you're born with, but it can happen later in life. It cannot usually be cured, but there are treatments to help the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Pulmonary fibrosis, see Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
explanation: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a condition in which the lungs become scarred and breathing becomes increasingly difficult.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Impetigo is a skin infection that's very contagious but not usually serious. Anyone can get it, but it's more common in young children. With treatment, impetigo often gets better in a few days.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Urinary incontinence is the unintentional passing of urine. It's a common problem thought to affect millions of people.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Most people have indigestion (dyspepsia) at some point. Usually, it's not a sign of anything more serious and you can treat it yourself.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An infected piercing can be serious if it's not treated quickly. Get immediate medical help if you think your piercing is infected.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Infertility is when a couple cannot get pregnant (conceive) despite having regular unprotected sex.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Ingrown hairs cause bumps, which are often itchy, where a hair has grown back into the skin. There are things you can do to treat and prevent them and in most cases you will not need to a see a GP for treatment.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: An ingrown toenail is a common problem where the nail grows into the toe. It can be painful, but there are things you can do to ease the pain.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Sting or bite (insect), see Insect bites and stings
explanation: Insect bites or stings are not usually serious and get better in a few days. But sometimes they can become infected or cause a serious allergic reaction.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Insomnia means you regularly have problems sleeping. It usually gets better by changing your sleeping habits.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Japanese encephalitis is a rare but serious infection you can get from mosquito bites in some parts of the world. If you're travelling to an area where there's a risk of catching it, you can get a vaccine to help prevent it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Jaundice is when your skin or the whites of your eyes turn yellow. It can be a sign of something serious, such as liver disease, so you need to get urgent medical help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Jaundice in newborn babies is common and usually harmless. It causes yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes. The medical term for jaundice in babies is neonatal jaundice.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Temporomandibular disorder (TMD) is a condition affecting the movement of the jaw. It's not usually serious and generally gets better on its own.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Jellyfish and other sea creature stings
explanation: Most stings from sea creatures in the UK are not serious and can be treated with first aid. Sometimes you may need to go to hospital.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Jet lag is when your normal sleep pattern is disturbed after a long flight. It usually improves within a few days as your body adjusts to the new time zone.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Joint hypermobility syndrome is when you have very flexible joints (you may think of yourself as being double-jointed). It usually affects children and young people and often gets better as you get older.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Kawasaki disease is a condition that mainly affects children under the age of 5. It's also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A keloid scar is a raised scar left on the skin after a wound has healed. You cannot get rid of it, but treatment can help improve how it looks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Keratosis pilaris is a very common harmless condition where small bumps appear on your skin. It can last for a long time, but there are treatments that may help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Find out about kidney cancer, including the symptoms, causes, tests, treatments, and where to get support.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A kidney infection is a painful type of urinary tract infection that can affect one or both kidneys. It can be serious if it's not treated.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Kidney stones can develop in 1 or both kidneys and most often affect people aged 30 to 60.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Klinefelter syndrome (sometimes called Klinefelter's, KS or XXY) is where boys and men are born with an extra X chromosome.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A meniscus tear is a common type of damage to cartilage in the knee. The cartilage is found between the bones in the knee joint and protects them when you move. It usually gets damaged because of an injury.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Knock knees is when there's a gap between your ankles when you stand with your knees together. It's common in children aged 3 to 6 and usually gets better on its own as they grow without causing any problems. Sometimes older children or adults can have it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Tooth knocked out, see Knocked-out tooth
explanation: You can usually save a knocked-out tooth by either putting it back in place, or in milk, as soon as possible before seeing a dentist. You should never put a baby tooth back in.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Kyphosis is a curve in the spine that makes the top of your back look hunched or rounded. Treatment may not be needed unless it’s severe or causing problems.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Labial fusion, or labial adhesion, is when the small inner lips around the entrance to the vagina become sealed together.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Laryngitis is when your voice box or vocal cords in the throat become irritated or swollen. It usually goes away by itself within 1 to 2 weeks.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A learning disability affects the way a person learns new things throughout their life.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Leg cramps are common, usually harmless, and only last a short time. They can happen at any time, but most people have them at night or when resting.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A leg ulcer is a long-lasting (chronic) sore that takes more than 2 weeks to heal. It usually develops on the inside of the leg, between the knee and the ankle.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Legionnaires' disease is a lung infection you can get from inhaling droplets of water from things like air conditioning or hot tubs. It's uncommon but it can be very serious.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Leptospirosis, also called Weil's disease, is an infection you can get from animals, soil or water. It's rare in the UK.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Leukoplakia is a white patch or patches in the mouth. If you have a white patch in your mouth that does not go away, get it checked by a dentist or GP.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Lichen planus is a rash that can affect different parts of your body, including the inside of your mouth. See a GP if you think you might have it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Lichen sclerosus is a skin condition that causes itchy white patches, most commonly on the genitals. There's no cure, but treatment can help relieve the symptoms.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Lipoedema is an abnormal build-up of fat in your legs and sometimes arms. It can be painful and affect daily life, but there are things you can do that may help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Lipomas are soft, fatty lumps that grow under your skin. They're harmless and do not usually need any treatment, but it's important to get any lumps checked by a GP.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Listeriosis is a rare infection caused by bacteria called listeria. It usually goes away on its own, but it can make some people seriously ill.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Liver cancer is a cancer that's found anywhere in the liver.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: There are many different types of liver disease. You can help prevent some of them by maintaining a healthy weight and staying within the recommended alcohol limits, if you drink.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Long COVID, sometimes called post-COVID syndrome, happens when the symptoms of COVID-19 last longer than 12 weeks. It's a new condition that's still being studied, but treatment can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a rare heart condition that's usually inherited. It can cause serious problems with your heart rhythm, but there are things you can do to reduce the risk.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Long-sightedness is where you find it hard to see things nearby, but you can see things far away clearly. It’s a common condition and wearing glasses or contact lenses can usually correct your vision.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Sperm count (low), see Low sperm count
explanation: Low sperm count is when there's a low amount of sperm in your semen. It can make it harder for you and your partner to get pregnant (conceive), but it may still be possible to conceive naturally and there are fertility treatments that can help.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: White blood cell count (low), see Low white blood cell count
explanation: A low white blood cell count usually means your body is not making enough white blood cells. It can increase your risk of getting infections.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Lung cancer is one of the most common and serious types of cancer. More than 43,000 people are diagnosed with the condition every year in the UK.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus) is a long-term condition that causes joint pain, skin rashes and tiredness. There's no cure, but symptoms can improve if treatment starts early.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection that can be spread to humans by infected ticks. It's usually easier to treat if it's diagnosed early.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Lymphoedema is a long-term (chronic) condition that causes swelling in the body's tissues. It can affect any part of the body, but usually develops in the arms or legs.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A macular hole is a small gap that opens at the centre of the retina, in an area called the macula.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Malaria is a serious infection spread by mosquitoes found in some parts of the world. You can die from it if it's not diagnosed and treated quickly.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Some men develop depression, loss of sex drive, erectile dysfunction, and other physical and emotional symptoms when they reach their late 40s to early 50s.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: A malignant brain tumour is a type of cancer that starts in the brain or spreads into the brain from another area of the body.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Mallet finger is an injury to the end of the finger, causing the tip to bend. It's a common sports injury and is treated using a splint.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Malnutrition is a serious condition that happens when your diet does not contain the right amount of nutrients.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Marfan syndrome is a disorder of the body's connective tissues, a group of tissues that maintain the structure of the body and support internal organs and other tissues.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Mastitis is when your breast becomes swollen, hot and painful.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Mastocytosis is a rare condition caused by an excess number of mast cells gathering in the body's tissues.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Mastoiditis is a serious infection that affects the mastoid bone behind the ear. It's more common in children and should be diagnosed and treated quickly.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Measles is an infection that spreads very easily and can cause serious problems in some people. Having the MMRV or MMR vaccine is the best way to prevent it.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

condition: Skin cancer (melanoma), see Melanoma skin cancer
explanation: There's another type of skin cancer called non-melanoma skin cancer. It's more common and usually less serious than melanoma.
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation: Meningitis is an infection of the protective membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord (meninges).
treatment_guidance: Please consult a healthcare professional for specific treatment advice relative to this condition.
referral: Refer to GP if symptoms persist.

explanation:
Page last reviewed: 17 May 2022
